text: FHFA: RIN 2590–AA43
label: HH1

text: Dear Regulators,
label: BODY

text: The Michigan Credit Union League (MCUL) appreciates the opportunity to comment on the
label: BODY

text: proposed rule issued by the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, the Federal Reserve
label: BODY

text: Board, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the Securities and Exchange Commission,
label: BODY

text: and the Federal Housing Finance Agency (collectively, the “Agencies”) to implement the risk
label: BODY

text: retention requirements and the definition of a Qualified Residential Mortgage (QRM), as
label: BODY

text: required by the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act’s (Dodd-Frank
label: BODY

text: Office of the Comptroller of the Currency
label: BODY

text: Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System
label: BODY

text: Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation
label: BODY

text: Securities and Exchange Commission
label: BODY

text: Federal Housing Finance Agency
label: BODY

text: August 1, 2011
label: BODY

text: Page 2
label: BODY

text: Act). MCUL is a statewide trade association representing 95% of the credit unions located in the
label: BODY

text: State of Michigan.
label: BODY

text: MCUL understands the necessity to address weaknesses and failures in the securitization
label: BODY

text: process and the securitization markets in response to the actions of unscrupulous mortgage
label: BODY

text: lenders who originated and sold high-risk, low-quality mortgage products that resulted in high-
label: BODY

text: risk, low-quality mortgage backed securities (MBSs).
label: BODY

text: Though the proposed rules were not designed to have a direct impact on the credit union
label: BODY

text: industry, credit unions and their respective members will be negatively impacted by the
label: BODY

text: definition of a Qualified Residential Mortgage (QRM), given that QRMs will very likely become
label: BODY

text: the industry standard for mortgage loans sold on the secondary market. As a result, credit
label: BODY

text: unions, especially smaller credit unions, will have to evaluate the burden of compliance costs of
label: BODY

text: this proposal and if excessive, there is a very real likelihood they could cut back on the type and
label: BODY

text: number of mortgage loan products offered, which in turn will have a negative impact on potential
label: BODY

text: mortgage loan borrowers.
label: BODY

text: MCUL strongly urges the Agencies to withdraw this proposed rule and issue a more reasonable
label: BODY

text: framework to address the weaknesses in the securitization process while ensuring that potential
label: BODY

text: borrowers have adequate access to mortgage credit.
label: BODY

text: Treatment of Government-Sponsored Enterprises (GSEs)
label: BODY

text: The proposed rule would exempt the Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae) and
label: BODY

text: the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation (Freddie Mac) (collectively, the GSEs) from the
label: BODY

text: 5% risk retention requirements while each is operating under the conservatorship or
label: BODY

text: receivership of the Federal Housing Finance Agency.
label: BODY

text: MCUL is concerned that this provision places the GSEs at an unfair advantage at a time when
label: BODY

text: many in the U.S. Congress are seeking to encourage more private-sector involvement as a
label: BODY

text: result of the poor performance of the GSEs in securitizing high-risk mortgages and purchasing
label: BODY

text: high-risk MSBs. Given the fact that the proposed rule provides evidence that less than 20% of
label: BODY

text: all residential mortgage loans purchased or repackaged by the GSEs from 1997 through 2009
label: BODY

text: would have met the proposed standards for QRMs, MCUL does not believe that such an
label: BODY

text: exemption would serve to improve the health of the residential mortgage loan industry.
label: BODY

text: Additionally, MCUL believes this exemption and the restrictive definition of a QRM will force
label: BODY

text: virtually all low down payment lending to the Federal Housing Agency (FHA), due to the fact that
label: BODY

text: FHA requires only a 3.5% down payment. This will increase borrower costs, reduce borrower
label: BODY

text: choice, and place non-FHA mortgage loan providers (like many credit unions) at a severe
label: BODY

text: disadvantage.
label: BODY

text: Office of the Comptroller of the Currency
label: BODY

text: Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System
label: BODY

text: Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation
label: BODY

text: Securities and Exchange Commission
label: BODY

text: Federal Housing Finance Agency
label: BODY

text: August 1, 2011
label: BODY

text: Page 3
label: BODY

text: Qualified Residential Mortgages
label: BODY

text: Overall Approach to Defining Qualifying Residential Mortgages
label: BODY

text: Despite the fact that the standards of a QRM would be very difficult for many potential
label: BODY

text: borrowers to achieve, the Agencies believe that “the amount of non-QRM residential mortgages
label: BODY

text: should be sufficiently large, and include enough prudently underwritten loans, so that ABS
label: BODY

text: backed by non-QRM residential mortgages may be routinely issued and purchased by a wide
label: BODY

text: variety of investors.” MCUL believes in order for this to be accurate, the Agencies would have
label: BODY

text: to assume that securitizers would be readily willing to comply with the complex risk retention
label: BODY

text: and disclosure requirements under the proposed rule, and that non-FHA QRMs will even remain
label: BODY

text: an acceptable option for potential borrowers.  MCUL believes that there is a much greater
label: BODY

text: incentive to offer QRMs in order to reduce the already overwhelming and ever-increasing
label: BODY

text: regulatory burden, which will have a directly negative impact on the availability of mortgage
label: BODY

text: credit, especially for low- to moderate-income consumers.
label: BODY

text: In considering how to determine whether a mortgage is of sufficient credit quality, the Agencies
label: BODY

text: examined data from various sources and reviewed specific aspects of borrowers who defaulted
label: BODY

text: on their respective mortgages. The Agencies then appeared to take each element that may
label: BODY

text: have contributed to a default and combined them to define the QRM.  MCUL believes the
label: BODY

text: definition of a QRM is inconsistent with prudent underwriting practices and the assessment of
label: BODY

text: credit risk that take different criteria into account to determine whether the low-risk factors offset
label: BODY

text: the higher-risk factors.
label: BODY

text: Borrower Credit History
label: BODY

text: Under the proposed rule, a borrower could not qualify for a QRM if currently 30 days late, in
label: BODY

text: whole or in part, on any debt obligation; 60 days or more days late on any debt obligation within
label: BODY

text: the preceding 24 months; or, within the past 36 months the borrower had been a debtor in
label: BODY

text: bankruptcy, had property repossessed or foreclosed upon, had engaged in a short sale or deed­
label: BODY

text: in-lieu of foreclosure, or had been subject to a Federal or State judgment for collection of any
label: BODY

text: unpaid debt.
label: BODY

text: While much of this criteria is reasonable and generally taken into account by prudent
label: BODY

text: underwriters, there are many legitimate reasons why a consumer would be 30 days late on a
label: BODY

text: payment that do not relate to the ability to repay a mortgage loan or the overall creditworthiness
label: BODY

text: of a borrower. Additionally, the proposed rule does not define a “debt obligation.”  A late
label: BODY

text: mortgage payment might be a good indication of an inability to repay a new mortgage loan, but
label: BODY

text: a late electric bill does not provide sufficient evidence that a borrower is a credit risk on a new
label: BODY

text: mortgage loan.
label: BODY

text: MCUL is not as optimistic as the Agencies that non-QRMs would be available for potential
label: BODY

text: borrowers, and believes the end result of this provision of the proposal would be that borrowers
label: BODY

text: Office of the Comptroller of the Currency
label: BODY

text: Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System
label: BODY

text: Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation
label: BODY

text: Securities and Exchange Commission
label: BODY

text: Federal Housing Finance Agency
label: BODY

text: August 1, 2011
label: BODY

text: Page 4
label: BODY

text: who had spent years to save for the required 20% down payment and were inadvertently late on
label: BODY

text: one payment would be denied mortgage credit.  MCUL does not believe this was the intent of
label: BODY

text: the United States Congress when the Dodd-Frank Act was deliberated or passed.
label: BODY

text: Payment Terms
label: BODY

text: The proposed rule would prohibit QRMs from having, among other features, payment terms that
label: BODY

text: allow interest-only payments, negative amortization, or adjustable-rate mortgages with interest
label: BODY

text: rates that do not exceed prescribed limits under the proposal.
label: BODY

text: Credit unions mortgage loan portfolios have performed well during the mortgage meltdown due
label: BODY

text: to strong underwriting practices and lower-risk mortgage product offerings, even though many of
label: BODY

text: those loans were provided to borrowers who would not have been approved under the proposed
label: BODY

text: QRM standards. MCUL strongly supports limiting the availability of high-risk mortgage loan
label: BODY

text: features, and believes the focus should be on the types of mortgages that pose the greatest risk
label: BODY

text: to the residential mortgage market rather than placing restrictions on those that do not.
label: BODY

text: Loan-to-Value (LTV) Ratio
label: BODY

text: For purchase mortgage transactions, the proposed rule would require an LTV ratio of 80%; 75%
label: BODY

text: on rate and refinance loans; and 70% for cash-out refinance loans.
label: BODY

text: MCUL is concerned that these provisions will have the effect of reducing the number of eligible
label: BODY

text: borrowers for mortgage loans, and will prevent the refinancing of loans that are in the best
label: BODY

text: interest of many homeowners.
label: BODY

text: MCUL urges the Agencies to re-examine these proposed provisions in order to further study the
label: BODY

text: impact of private mortgage insurance on loans with higher LTV ratios, given that such insurers
label: BODY

text: may be willing to accept the risks of default.
label: BODY

text: Down Payment
label: BODY

text: The proposed rule would require borrowers to provide a 20% down payment (plus costs) in
label: BODY

text: order to qualify for a QRM. MCUL believes this requirement is harsh and will likely force
label: BODY

text: otherwise qualified borrowers, who could afford to make monthly mortgage payments with some
label: BODY

text: smaller amount of down payment, or a combination of a smaller amount of down payment and
label: BODY

text: PMI, out of the mortgage market for decades. Low-to-moderate income consumers would very
label: BODY

text: likely lose the opportunity to achieve the dream of home ownership permanently.
label: BODY

text: The Agencies appear to have recognized this fact in its footnoted statement that “while many
label: BODY

text: creditworthy homebuyers seeking to purchase a home will likely not have the 20% down
label: BODY

text: payment required for a QRM, sound underwriting of these loans may well require the prudent
label: BODY

text: use of judgment about the borrower’s ability to repay the loan and other risk mitigants that are
label: BODY

text: Office of the Comptroller of the Currency
label: BODY

text: Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System
label: BODY

text: Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation
label: BODY

text: Securities and Exchange Commission
label: BODY

text: Federal Housing Finance Agency
label: BODY

text: August 1, 2011
label: BODY

text: Page 5
label: BODY

text: likely to change over time and vary from borrower to borrower.”  MCUL agrees with this
label: BODY

text: statement, and does not believe this provision of the proposed rule represents the intention of
label: BODY

text: the U.S. Congress when deliberating and passing the Dodd-Frank Act.  MCUL strongly urges
label: BODY

text: the Agencies to reconsider its position to require borrowers to put 20% down on a home in order
label: BODY

text: to qualify for a QRM.
label: BODY

text: The proposed rule would not consider the risk mitigation effects of mortgage guarantee
label: BODY

text: insurance or other credit enhancements obtained at the time of origination, as the Agencies
label: BODY

text: “have not identified studies or historical loan performance data adequately demonstrating that
label: BODY

text: mortgages with such credit enhancements are less likely to default than other mortgages.”
label: BODY

text: MCUL urges the Agencies to reconsider this position. Borrowers that do not have a 20% down
label: BODY

text: payment, but otherwise meet responsible underwriting criteria, receive a valuable benefit from
label: BODY

text: mortgage guarantee insurance. Without it, borrowers would either be confronted with having to
label: BODY

text: pay exponentially more to obtain a mortgage loan, or be prevented from obtaining home
label: BODY

text: ownership status for a much longer period of time in order to save enough money for a down
label: BODY

text: payment. MCUL respectfully submits that while there does not appear to be any evidence to
label: BODY

text: suggest that mortgages with mortgage guarantee insurance or other credit enhancements are
label: BODY

text: less likely to default than other mortgages, there is no evidence to suggest that mortgages with
label: BODY

text: these additional products are any more likely to default than mortgages without them.
label: BODY

text: Qualifying Appraisal
label: BODY

text: A QRM would be required to be supported by a written appraisal that conforms to generally
label: BODY

text: accepted appraisal standards, as evidenced by the Uniform Standards of Professional Appraisal
label: BODY

text: Practice, the appraisal requirements of the Federal banking agencies, and applicable laws.
label: BODY

text: MCUL supports this provision as part of the definition of a QRM.
label: BODY

text: Ability to Repay
label: BODY

text: The rule proposes a front-end debt-to-income (DTI) ratio limit of 28% and a back-end ratio limit
label: BODY

text: of 36%. For purposes of calculating these proposed ratios, the proposal would require
label: BODY

text: originators to use the borrower’s monthly gross income, as determined in accordance with the
label: BODY

text: effective income standards set forth in the HUD Handbook, which have been incorporated into
label: BODY

text: the Additional QRM Standards Appendix to the proposed rules.
label: BODY

text: While MCUL believes that DTI ratios are an appropriate risk indicator for residential mortgages,
label: BODY

text: the proposal would require this ratio to be viewed in isolation. MCUL believes the proposed
label: BODY

text: back-end DTI of 36% is overly restrictive and should be relaxed so long as low-risk mitigating
label: BODY

text: factors are also present in the underwriting process.  MCUL urges the Agencies to amend these
label: BODY

text: provisions in order to prevent otherwise creditworthy borrowers from obtaining home ownership.
label: BODY

text: Office of the Comptroller of the Currency
label: BODY

text: Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System
label: BODY

text: Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation
label: BODY

text: Securities and Exchange Commission
label: BODY

text: Federal Housing Finance Agency
label: BODY

text: August 1, 2011
label: BODY

text: Page 6
label: BODY

text: Points and Fees
label: BODY

text: Under the proposal, in order for a mortgage to qualify as a QRM, the total points and fees
label: BODY

text: payable by the borrower in connection with the mortgage transaction shall not exceed 3% of the
label: BODY

text: total loan amount, which would be calculated in the same manner as in Regulation Z.  MCUL
label: BODY

text: does not see the correlation between higher points and fees and mortgage default, and urges
label: BODY

text: the Agencies to remove these criteria from the definition of a QRM.
label: BODY

text: Assumability Prohibition
label: BODY

text: Under the proposed rules, a QRM could not be assumable by any person who was not a
label: BODY

text: borrower under the original mortgage transaction.
label: BODY

text: Many home owners have taken advantage of the low-rate market by refinancing their existing
label: BODY

text: mortgages for lower rate options. In a rising interest rate market, potential borrowers may
label: BODY

text: choose to assume an existing low-rate mortgage rather than seeking a higher mortgage loan
label: BODY

text: amount with a higher interest rate.  Provided the purchaser otherwise met the criteria of a QRM-
label: BODY

text: qualified borrower, MCUL does not see the risk that an assumed mortgage would pose. MCUL
label: BODY

text: urges the Agencies to reconsider this provision of the proposed rule.
label: BODY

text: Conclusion
label: BODY

text: While MCUL appreciates the difficult task the Agencies were charged with in order to mitigate
label: BODY

text: risk in the mortgage market, MCUL believes this proposed rule will end up harming the still
label: BODY

text: fragile residential mortgage industry the rule was designed to protect, as the number of eligible
label: BODY

text: borrowers and the availability of attainable mortgage credit would be severely reduced.
label: BODY

text: MCUL supports aspects of the proposed rule that focus on the types of high-risk, exotic
label: BODY

text: mortgage products that were packaged into high-risk MSBs that the Dodd-Frank Act was
label: BODY

text: designed to limit. MCUL strongly urges the Agencies to focus on mortgages that pose the
label: BODY

text: greatest risk to the residential mortgage market rather than broadly restricting those that do not
label: BODY

text: when crafting a definition of a QRM.
label: BODY

text: MCUL appreciates the opportunity to comment.
label: BODY

text: Sincerely,
label: BODY

text: VP Regulatory Affairs
label: BODY
